column1: 1995ApJ...446..842M|1995|EUVE Observations of the Anomalous 1993 August Outburst of SS Cygni|Mauche
column6: Janet A.|The Astrophysical Journal|446||842|Target-of-opportunity observations of the dwarf nova SS Cygni were made by the Extreme Ultraviolet Explorer (EUVE) satellite between 1993 August 17.1 and 23.6 UT (MJD 9216.6 and 9223.1). The observations cover the rise and plateau phases of an anomalous outburst which began on August 15.5 and which reached maximum at V ̃ 8.3 on August 20.5. During the observations
column7: the brightness of the source as measured by the Deep Survey instrument rose from ̃0.015 counts s<SUP>-1</SUP> to ̃5 counts s<SUP>-1</SUP>. A delay of ̃3 days was initially observed between the EUV and optical light curves
column8: but this delay decreased to zero as the light curves approached maximum. During the interval August 17.3 to 23.6 UT
column9: the 72-130 Å flux as measured by the Short Wavelength Spectrometer rose from ̃6 × 10<SUP>-13</SUP> to ̃6.7 × 10<SUP>11</SUP> ergs cm<SUP>-2</SUP>s<SUP>-1</SUP>
column10: while the 72-90 Å to 90-130 A count ratio remained constant at 1.39±0.05. Parameterizing the EUV spectrum with a blackbody absorbed by a column of cold neutral material
column11: we derive the luminosity L<SUB>bl</SUB> and fractional emitting area f = L<SUB>bl</SUB>/4πR<SUP>2</SUP><SUB>wd</SUB>σT<SUP>4</SUP> of the boundary layer as a function of temperature kT. For kT = 30 eV
column17: and f ̃ 3 × 10<SUP>3</SUP>. The optical through far-UV luminosity of the accretion disk in outburst is L<SUB>disk</SUB> ̃ 3 × 10<SUP>3</SUP> ergs s<SUP>-1</SUP>. Therefore
column18: while simple theory predicts that the luminosities of the boundary layer and accretion disk should be comparable unless the white dwarf is rotating very rapidly
column20: we find that ζ ≲ 0.07. The most interesting and enigmatic aspect of these observations is the EUV spectrum
column21: which evolved homologously over roughly two orders of magnitude in luminosity. The constancy of the EUV spectrum over such a wide range of brightness seems impossible to reconcile with the standard picture of boundary layer emission.
